title: A Complete Guide to Pine Tree Identification

steps.title: Clusters of long, soft needles
steps.content: Clusters of long, soft needles Pines have somewhat soft, bendy needles, so you can quickly eliminate trees that have regular leaves on their branches. [1] X Research source Pine needles grow in clusters, stemming from one single origin point. The clusters of pine needles will either be in twos, threes, or fives. [2] X Research source If you touch the needles and they feel bendy, this is an indication that it’s a pine tree. [3] X Research source The base of the needle cluster will be wrapped in a papery sheath (also known as a fascicle). [4] X Research source If you see clusters of 2, this is a red pine, while clusters of 3 are yellow pines, and clusters of 5 are white pines. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Stiff, reddish-brown cones that hang downward
steps.content: Stiff, reddish-brown cones that hang downward Mature pine cones are reddish-brown, or possibly black. [6] X Research source They’re hard and wood-like when you touch them, as opposed to other conifers’ cones which are much thinner and paper-like. Pine cones hang towards the ground, while fir cones stand upright. Young pine cones might appear to be growing upward, but as they mature, they’ll begin to droop and point downward.

steps.title: Points in the middle of each cone scale
steps.content: Points in the middle of each cone scale Pine cones can sometimes be identified by the unique points on certain species’ scales. Look at the end of each scale and see if the middle of the scale comes to a point. If it does, this is likely a pine cone. [7] X Research source Pine cone scales can be so tightly closed together when they are immature that the exposed portions form a striking pattern of many diamonds, Simpson shares. [8] X Expert Source Michael Simpson, PhD Registered Professional Biologist Expert Interview. 14 July 2021. He also notes that some pine cones have very sharp spines in the center of each diamond. Look out for this before you grab a pine cone for a closer look! [9] X Expert Source Michael Simpson, PhD Registered Professional Biologist Expert Interview. 14 July 2021.

steps.title: Thin foliage and a loose shape overall
steps.content: Thin foliage and a loose shape overall While coniferous trees have a triangle-like structure, pine trees tend to have a less well-defined shape, notes Simpson. [10] X Expert Source Michael Simpson, PhD Registered Professional Biologist Expert Interview. 14 July 2021. Pine trees shed their oldest needles after roughly 3 years, which can leave them with less foliage. They may also lose their lower branches as they age, while most spruces and firs retain a triangular Christmas-tree shape in maturity. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Found in the mountains of the Northern Hemisphere
steps.content: Found in the mountains of the Northern Hemisphere Pine trees live and grow primarily in the Northern Hemisphere, and they like having access to the sunlight. While not every pine tree grows on a mountain, pines are abundant in mountainous areas. [12] X Research source They tend to grow in sandy soil, and don’t like swampy land that doesn’t drain easily. [13] X Research source Pines are able to thrive in colder weather and at a higher altitude, making them perfect mountain trees.

steps.title: Eastern White Pine (Pinus strobus)
steps.content: Eastern White Pine ( Pinus strobus ) The white pine is the state tree of Maine. White pine trees have clusters of five needles that are bluish-green or silver-green in color. [14] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source Eastern white pine cones have a sticky resin with a noticeable scent. [15] X Research source White pine needles usually grow to be 2 1 ⁄ 2 to 5 inches (6.4 to 12.7 cm) long. Unlike some pines’ cones, the scales of white pine cones never have prickles.

steps.title: Ponderosa Pine (Pinus ponderosa)
steps.content: Ponderosa Pine ( Pinus ponderosa ) Ponderosa pine trees are native to Western North America. They have clusters of two or three needles that grow between 5 to 11 inches (13 to 28 cm) long. Their bark smells like vanilla. They tend to have tall, bare trunks when mature. Their cones are prickly, so be careful when you grab one. Mature ponderosa pines have either an orange, brown, or reddish-brown bark color.

steps.title: Lodgepole Pine (Pinus contorta ssp. contorta)
steps.content: Lodgepole Pine ( Pinus contorta ssp. contorta ) Lodgepole pine trees are native to California. These trees have clusters of two needles that grow 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) long. Mature trees have dark bark that’s reddish-brown or close to black. Their unopened cones cling to the branches, staying for years. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Pitch Pine (Pinus rigida)
steps.content: Pitch Pine ( Pinus rigida ) Pitch pine trees, an Eastern variety, have clusters of three needles that are usually 3 to 5 inches (7.6 to 12.7 cm) long. The needles are dark yellow-green and may grow out of the trunk of the tree. They tend to be thick and sharp, unlike the soft needles of some other pine varieties. [17] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source Pitch pine bark is either reddish-brown or gray, and features scales.

steps.title: Jeffrey Pine (Pinus jeffreyi)
steps.content: Jeffrey Pine ( Pinus jeffreyi ) Jeffrey pine trees have clusters of three needles, growing from 7 to 11 inches (18 to 28 cm) long. They’re found throughout Western North America. While Jeffrey pine cones have prickles, they curve inward, giving the tree the nickname “gentle Jeffrey” because it won’t poke you like a ponderosa pine cone might. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Sugar Pine (Pinus lambertiana)
steps.content: Sugar Pine ( Pinus lambertiana ) Sugar pine trees are the largest of all pine trees, growing between 130 to 200 feet (40 to 61 m) tall. They have clusters of five needles and cones that can grow to over 20 inches (51 cm). These impressive trees are found along the West coast of North America. [19] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source

steps.title: Fir
steps.content: Fir Fir trees are easily distinguished from pines because their needles grow individually, Simpson says. [20] X Expert Source Michael Simpson, PhD Registered Professional Biologist Expert Interview. 14 July 2021. To distinguish a fir tree from a spruce tree, feel its needles. While spruce needles can be rolled between your fingers, fir needles are flatter and can’t be rolled. [21] X Research source Another thing to look for is the direction the cones grow in—fir cones are fragile and grow upright like thin candles.

steps.title: Spruce
steps.content: Spruce Like fir trees, spruce trees have individual needles that don’t grow in clusters. “Spruce trees have shorter needles [than pine trees] that appear to grow directly from each branch, and they’re spaced close together, like bristles on a hairbrush,” Simpson explains. [22] X Expert Source Michael Simpson, PhD Registered Professional Biologist Expert Interview. 14 July 2021. Spruce cones resemble pine cones, but have less rigid scales and feel less woody to the touch. If you can break a scale off the cone, it’s probably a spruce.

steps.title: Cedar
steps.content: Cedar True cedars have needles that are flat and scale-like, with a kind of scalloped edge on each side. [23] X Research source This is the easiest way to tell them apart from pines, which have long, thin, smooth needles. Cedar cones grow upright and resemble rose buds. Cedar has a distinctive smell that’s pungent and featured in many fragrances.

steps.title: Hemlock
steps.content: Hemlock Hemlock trees have flat needles that are small and blunted, growing parallel from one another along the twig in pairs. Their cones are noted for their small size. [24] X Research source Additionally, hemlock needles are attached to the twig via a small stem, while fir needles appear stuck directly into the twig. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Larch
steps.content: Larch Larches are deciduous conifers, not evergreens. This means their needles turn yellow and fall off in autumn. [26] X Research source Other ways to tell larches apart from other conifers are that their needles feel soft and fuzzy to the touch, and they’re a vibrant green color in spring and summer that stands out from a pine or spruce’s dark green. [27] X Research source

steps.title: Juniper
steps.content: Juniper Juniper needles have a distinctive look that sets them apart from other trees. Their needles are either scale-like or awl-shaped. [28] X Research source The scaly needles resemble the woven pattern of a shoelace, but spikier. The awl-shaped needles resemble a lavender flower. Their cones are blue and berry-like—another standout feature. [29] X Research source
